choices.text: Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the anatomical snuffbox ?
questions.solution:
Anatomical snuff box

- It is a triangular depression on posterolateral side of the wrist.

- It seen best when the thumb is extended.

- Boundaries :

Medial : Extensor pollicis longus

Lateral : Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

Floor : Scaphoid, trapezium, base of 1st metacarpal

- Contents : Superficial branch of radial nerve , Cephalic vein and Radial artery.

- Tenderness in the floor of anatomical snuff box - indicated scaphoid fracture

choices.text: Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis

questions.text: A 30 year female patient is presenting with wrist pain on lateral side. On examination following test was positive. Tendon sheath of which two muscles have been involved:
questions.solution:
- The test show in image is Finkelstein's test.

- This test is done to determine if there is Tenosynovitis in abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons of the wrist.

- The condition is called de Quervain's disease that give rise to pain on lateral side of the wrist.

questions.text: Identify the cell marked in the histological image of the cerebellum shown below :
questions.solution:
- The cell marked in given image of cerebellum is purkinje cells.

- Cerebellar cortex has a three distinct layers:

  • Outer Molecular Layer
  • Intermediate Purkinje cell layer
  • Inner granular layer
  1. Outer Molecular layer consists 2 types of nerve cell -Basket cell & Stellate cell. This layer also consists dendritic arborization of Purkinje cell.
  2. Intermediate Purkinje cell layer: consists single row of Large flask shaped Purkinje cells.
  3. Inner Granular layer: consists of 2 type of nerve cells -granular cells & Golgi cells.
    • All these cells are inhibitory except granular cells which are excitatory
    • The efferent from cerebellar cortex is purkinje cells which relay to deep cerebellar nuclei
    • The efferent from entire cerebellum is deep cerebellar nuclei

questions.text: Which is not used in identification of facial nerve trunk in parotid surgery ?
questions.solution:
-The facial nerve leaves the skull by passing through stylomastoid foramen.

-The facial nerve enters the posteromedial surface of parotid gland, runs forwards through the gland crossing retromandibular vein and external carotid artery.

-Behind the neck of mandible, it divides into two branches -Temporofacial and Cervicofacial . Temporofacial gives temporal and zygomatic branches. Cervicofacial gives buccal, marginal mandibular and cervical braches. These five terminal branches emerges along the anterior border and apex of the parotid gland.

-In parotid surgery, facial nerve trunk can identified by tympanomastoid suture line, Tragal cartilage and digastric groove.

-Inferior belly of omohyoid is not used for identification of facial nerve trunk, instead posterior belly of digastric is used for identification of facial nerve

questions.text: A 54 year old man comes to hospital with abdominal pain, jaundice , loss of appetite and weight loss. On examination of radiogram and CT scan, a physician finds a slowly growing Tumor of the uncinate process of pancreas. Which of the following strucutre is most likely compressed by tumour ?
questions.solution:
• Parts of pancreas:Head, Neck, Body and Tail.
  • The head has three borders-superior, inferior and right lateral; two surfaces-anterior and posterior.
  • One process, projects from the lower and left part of the head towards left is called the Uncinate process.
  • Uncinate process: It is related anteriorly to the superior mesenteric vessels, and posteriorly to the aorta.
  • Tumour of the Uncinate process of pancreas affects the superior mesenteric vessels.

questions.text: A patient presented with features of ataxia and incoordination. Which of the arteries is affected?
questions.solution:
The feature ataxia and incoordination suggestive of cerebellar syndrome.

  • Symptoms of cerebellar syndrome:
    • Truncal ataxia
    • Staggering gait
    • Nystagmus
    • Hypotonia
    • Asthesia
    • Flail joints
  • Blood Supply of cerebellum:
    • Superior cerebellar artery
    • Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
    • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • So blockage of superior cerebellar arteries leads to ataxia and incoordination.

questions.text: Which strucutre prevents the upward extension of thyroid swelling through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage ?
questions.solution:
• The false capsule is derived from the pretracheal layer of the deep cervical fascia.
  • It is thin along the posterior border of the lobes, but thick on the inner surface of the gland where it forms a suspensory ligament (of Berry), which connects the lobe to the cricoid cartilage.

It is preventing upward extension of thyroid swelling.

questions.text: A patient presented with extension of metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint and flexion of Interphalangeal (IP) joint. Which muscle is involved?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario suggest that the patient has claw hand

LUMBRICALS:

  1. 1st and 2nd lumbrical ( unipennate) -innervated by median nerve
  2. 3rd and 4th lumbrical (bipennate)-innervated by ulnar nerve
  3. Action of lumbricals: Flex metacarpophalangeal joints, Extend interphalangeal joints of 2nd-5th digits

INTEROSSEI:

  1. Palmar interossei (unipennate): adduction of fingers
  2. Dorsal interossei (bipennate)-abduction of fingers
  3. Interossei are innervated by ulnar nerve
  • The lumbricals and interossei are tested by asking the subject to flex the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints against resistance.
  • If lumbricals involved-then the action of lumbricals are lost and the patient presents with extension of metacarpophalangeal joint and flexion of IP joint occurs.

questions.text: Meiosis occurs in.
questions.solution:
• The meiosis is a special type of cell division that takes place only in the reproductive organs to produce gametes. (Ovary and testis)
  • The meiosis consists of two phases of cell divisions that take place one after the other.
    • First meiotic division (also known as reductional division): In this the number of chromosomes of the daughter cells is reduced to half of the mother cell.
    • The second meiotic division: It is the mitotic division similar to one described above except that there is no duplication of DNA during short interphase.
    • So ovary

questions.text: Fertilization occurs in which part of the fallopian tube?
questions.solution:
• The fallopian tube has four part from medial to lateral : Interstitial, Isthmus, Ampulla and Infundibulum.
  • The fertilization is the process of fusion of male and female gametes (pronuclei) to form a zygote.
  • It takes place within 24 hours of ovulation, in the most dilated part of the uterine tube-the ampulla.
  • The results of fertilization are:
    • Determination of genetic sex of embryo
    • Restoration of diploid number of chromosomes
    • Initiation of cleavage.
  • The fertilization is essential for propagation of species and their evolution.

questions.text: Left recurrent laryngeal nerve is longer due to persistence of which arch artery?
questions.solution:
• The recurrent laryngeal nerves (nerve of 6th pharyngeal arch) initially hook around the sixth arch artery on the respective side.
  • On right side: Because of the distal part of the sixth arch artery disappears, the right recurrent laryngeal nerve moves superiorly and hook around the proximal part of right subclavian artery (the derivatives of 4th arch artery
  • On left side: the left recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks around the distal part of sixth arch artery, which persists as Ductus arteriosus. When DA obliterates after birth to form ligamentum arteriosus, the left recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks around the ligamentum arteriosus (left sixth arch artery derivative).

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the muscle marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
• It is a Levator Scapulae muscle.
  • Origin:
    • Transverse processes of C1, C2
    • Posterior tubercles of the transverse processes of C3, C4
  • Insertion:
    • Superior angle and upper part of medial border (up to triangular area) of the scapula
  • Nerve supply:
    • A branch from dorsal scapular nerve (C5)
    • Branches from C3, C4
  • Action:
    • Helps in elevation of scapula

Steadies the scapula during movements of the arm

questions.text: In a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome, which of the following type of cell is deficient:
questions.solution:
- In preterm baby, respiratory distress syndrome is due to deficiency of pulmonary surfactant.

- The pulmonary surfactant reduces the surface tension and prevents collapse of the alveolus during expiration.

- The pulmonary surfactant is produced by Type II alveolar cells.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of right side of the face with loss of pain and temperature. Pain and temperature sensation of the left leg is also lost. The lesion is at :
questions.solution:
- A patient has weakness of right side of face : due to lesion in facial nerve.

- Loss of pain and temperature of face: Lesion of spinal nucleus and tract of trigeminal nerve.

- Loss of pain temperature of leg : due to lesion of corticospinal tract.

- Above signs and symptoms suggestive of lesion at lateral pons.

choices.text: Right gastric artery and right gastroepiploic artery
Right gastric artery and left gastric artery
Right gastroepiploic artery and short gastric artery
Right gastric artery and short gastric artery

questions.text: Ligation of the common hepatic artery will impair the blood supply to which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Branches of the common hepatic artery:
  • The gastroduodenal artery: which divides into two branches
    • Right gastroepiploic artery
    • Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery
  • Cystic artery
  • Right gastric artery
  • Proper hepatic artery

- The branches of coeliac trunk are as follow :

questions.text: Identify the type of joint in the given picture.
questions.solution:
• It is a Costovertebral joint.
  • The head of a typical rib articulates with its own vertebra, and also with the body of the next higher vertebra, to form two plane synovial cavities separated by an intra-articular ligament.
  • This ligament is attached to the ridge on the head of the rib and to the intervertebral disc.

questions.text: A patient presented with an enlarged inguinal lymph node. Primary cause is due to carcinoma of
questions.solution:
- Lymphatics from glans penis drain into deep inguinal node also called gland of Cloquet. Lymphatics from the rest of the penis drain into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

- Lymphatics from testis ascend along testicular vessels and drain into the preaortic and paraaortic groups of lymph nodes.

- Lymphatics from the urinary bladder terminates into external iliac nodes

- Lymphatics from the prostate drain chiefly into the internal iliac and sacral nodes and partly into external iliac nodes.

questions.text: Identify the cartilage shown below
questions.solution:
- Elastic cartilage:

  • Chondrocytes are present as single in lacunae in between elastic fibres.
  • Matrix contains branching and anastomosing elastic fibres.
  • Surface is covered by perichondrium.
  • It possesses greater flexibility and readily recovers shape after being deformed

- The difference in three types of cartilages is as follow:

questions.text: Where is the remnant of wolffian duct in females located?
questions.solution:
• Two pairs of genital ducts develop in both sexes.
  • Mesonephric ducts (wolffian Ducts)
  • Paramesonephric ducts (Mullerian ducts)
  • In male mesonephric ducts form the genital ducts and in females it disappears.
  • In female paramesonephric ducts form the female genital ducts and in male it mostly disappears.
  • Epoophoron: persistent cranial part of mesonephric duct (in female)
  • Contents of broad ligament of uterus:
    • The uterine tube
    • The round ligament of the uterus
    • The ligament of the ovary
    • Uterine vessels & Ovarian vessels
    • The uterovaginal and ovarian nerve plexuses
    • Epoophoron & Paroophoron
    • Some lymph nodes and lymph vessels
    • Dense connective tissue or parametrium present the sides of the uterus

- The Vestigial remnants of mesonephric duct (wolffian duct) in females are as follow:

questions.text: A 65 years old lady presents with a cerebrovascular accident involving inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area would be mostly effected ?
questions.solution:
- The motor speech area of Broca is located in the pars triangularis (Area 44) and pars opercularis (Area 45) of inferior frontal gyrus of dominant hemisphere.

- Broca's area is responsible for production of expressive speech/vocalization. It brings about the formation of words by its connections with adjacent primary motor area, which in turn stimulate the muscles of speaking apparatus consisting of the lips, mouth, tongue , soft palate, larynx and respiratory muscles.

- Lesion of motor speech area result in loss of ability to produce speech i.e expressive aphasia ( Motor aphasia).

questions.text: A boy met with a motor bike accident. CT Brain shows injury to posterior end of superior temporal gyrus. He is likely to suffer from
questions.solution:
- The sensory speech area of Wernicke is located in the posterior part of superior temporal gyrus of temporal lobe and angular (area 39) and supramarginal ( area 40) gyri of the inferior parietal lobule.

- The Wernicke's area is concerned with interpretation of language through visual and auditory input. It also helps in understanding the speech and using correct words to express our thoughts.

- Lesion in Wernicke's area produce loss of ability to understand the spoken and written speech. The  expressive speech is unimpaired and the individual can produce a fluent speech.

questions.text: A man was brought to emergency after meeting with an accident and injured perineum. He feels an urge to micturate but is unable to pass urine. There is blood at the tip of meatus with extensive swelling of penis and scrotum. What is the possible site of injury ?
questions.solution:
- Rupture of the urethra leads to extravasation of urine, which may be superficial or deep.

- In superficial extravasation, the urine spreads downwards deep to membranous layer of the superficial fascia. It first fills the superficial perineal space; and then scrotum, the penis and the lower part of anterior abdominal wall. It is prevented from going to the ischioanal fossa or the thigh by the firm attachment of the membranous layer of superficial fascia to their boundaries.

- In deep extravasation, the urine spreads upwards into the extraperitoneal space of the pelvis around bladder and prostate into anterior abdominal wall.

questions.text: Episiotomy incision was extended posteriorly beyond the perineal body injuring the strucutre immediately posterior to it. Which structure has been injured ?
questions.solution:
- Episiotomy : It is an incision given in the to enlarge the vaginal orifice to facilitate childbirth.

  • Median episiotomy : This incision begins at frenulum of labia minora and proceeds backwards in the midline up to the external anal sphincter . it cuts through skin, vaginal wall, perineal body and superficial transverse perinei muscle.
  • Mediolateral episiotomy : This incision begins at the labia minora and proceeds laterally at an angle of 45 degree. It cuts through skin, vaginal wall and Bulbospongiosus muscle.

questions.text: A 70 years old patient presented with history of fever, halitosis, night cough and regurgitation of food in mouth. On examination there is pulsatile swelling on left side of neck which produces gurgling sound on compression. What is the most likely diagnosis by looking at the barium swallow study on the patient ?
questions.solution:
• In the posterior wall of the pharynx, the lower part of the Thyropharyngeus (inferior constrictor) is a single sheet of muscle, not overlapped internally by the superior and middle constrictors.
  • This weak part lies below the level of the vocal folds or upper border of the cricoid lamina and is limited inferiorly by the thick cricopharyngeal sphincter.
  • This area is known as Killian's dehiscence. Pharyngeal diverticula are formed by outpouching of the dehiscence.
  • Such diverticula are normal in the pig.
  • Pharyngeal diverticula are often attributed to neuromuscular incoordination in this region which may be due to the fact that different nerves supply the two parts of the inferior constrictor.
  • The propulsive Thyropharyngeus is supplied by the pharyngeal plexus, and sphincter cricopharyngeal by the recurrent laryngeal nerve. If the Cricopharyngeus fails to relax when the Thyropharyngeus contracts, the bolus of food is pushed backwards, and tends to produce a diverticulum.

questions.text: Intractable cough reflex on scratching the floor of external acoustic meatus is due to which nerve ?
questions.solution:
- Nerve supply of Ear is as follow :

  • Upper 2/3 of lateral surface : Auriculotemporal nerve
  • Lower 1/3 of lateral surface : great auricular nerve
  • Upper 2/3 of medial surface : lesser occipital nerve
  • Lower 1/3 of medial surface : great auricular nerve
  • Root of the auricle : Auricular branch of vagus nerve.

questions.text: Clinical diagnosis for the patient shown in the diagram
questions.solution:
- Gastroschisis : There is a linear defect in anterior abdominal wall through which abdominal contents herniates out. It occurs lateral to the umbilicus, usually on to the right.

- option d) Omphalocele : It presents as rounded mass protruding from the umbilicus. This mass contains coils of small intestine and is covered by a transparent amniotic membrane. This anomaly results from failure of coils of small intestine to return into abdominal cavity from their physiological herniation into extraembryonic coelom during sixth to tenth week of IUL.

- option a) Meckel's diverticulum : It is a small diverticulum arising from antimesenteric border of ileum. It is a persistent part of Vitellointestinal duct.

- option d) Urachal diverticulum : It is a persistent part of a allontois.
